div.head: Astronomical Education
div.p: Between 1826 and 1828, astronomy featured persistently in Ruskinʼs poetry and prose, from his first mention of the typical beginnerʼs constellation for British children, Charlesʼs Wain, in the 1826/27 poem, “Glen of Glenfarg” [“Glen of Glenfarg thy beauteous rill”]; to his cataloguing of constellation names from all around the celestial globe in the 1827/28 poem, “The Constellations”; to his assigning the task of memorizing constellation names and their respective numbers of stars to his character Lucy in the dialogue, “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol III”; to his Miltonic hymn of praise in the New Yearʼs poem for January 1828, “The Sun”. Ruskin composed these works in context of rising popular education in astronomy for adults and children in the first three decades of the nineteenth century in Britain. On this evidence, he was engaged more by the poetic sublimity of the subject than by the science, although these works contain hints that he gained at least basic conceptual understanding of the solar system and the fixed stars.
div.div:
Print Sources of Astronomical Education
Star Atlases
In “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol III”, Ruskinʼs “Harry” “took one of his lesson books and made Lucy learn the following constellations with the number of stars” (chap. 1); and there follow lists of constellation names paired with their respective numbers of stars. The identity of Ruskinʼs “lesson book” has eluded detection since Harryʼs totals of stars have so far failed to match the statistics supplied in British astronomy texts commonly available in the 1820s. These counts of observable stars within the constellation boundaries changed over time, and the constellations themselves changed as new ones were added and others consigned to obsolescence, so Ruskinʼs source may yet be found. Or he may have devised his own method of counting stars, such as numbering only stars of a certain magnitude. Whatever the case, the kind of book normally associated with this exacting information was a star atlas.
For British amateur astronomers in the 1820s, the logical choice among star atlases was A Celestial Atlas Comprising a Systematic Display of the Heavens in a Series of Thirty Maps Illustrated by Scientific Descriptions of Their Contents, and Accompanied by Catalogues of the Stars and Astronomical Exercises by Alexander Jamieson (1782–1850). Published in 1822, followed by a reprint circa 1823–24, the Celestial Atlas was an advanced and up‐to‐date work by a Scottish‐ and English‐educated schoolmaster, which included lessons and exercises designed for “beginners, rather than . . . adepts in the science”, and which was “composed in a popular language, without any regard to the learned phraseology of Astronomers” (preface, ii). Embellished with plates elegantly rendering the mythical figures representing the constellations, Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas provided the British public with a star atlas that boasted a dedication to the king, George IV, and that could compete credibly with the French and German atlases then in common use. (For its publication history along with biographical information on Jamieson, see theRidpath, “Celestial Atlas by Alexander Jamieson”).
Notwithstanding Jamiesonʼs target audience of “beginners, rather than . . . adepts”, any star atlas would have posed a daunting text for Ruskin at ages seven to nine. In 1835, when he was sixteen, the Ruskins may have acquired a different textbook by Jamieson, A Grammar of Logic and Intellectual Philosophy on Didactic Principles (1819). (Dearden identifies this text predicated on an entry, “Jamieson 6/6”, for 14 May 1835 in John James Ruskinʼs Account Book [39v], an entry that, as Van Akin Burd admits, could apply, not just to various works by Alexander Jamieson but also to works by the geologist Robert Jamieson [1774–1854]. See Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 183 [no. 1405]; and Ruskin Family Letters, ed. Burd, 300–301 n. 12. Identification of this item recorded in John Jamesʼs accounts as a textbook by Alexander Jamieson is therefore problematic, although Dearden correlates this item with a gift to the Working Menʼs College in 1858.)
Even if Ruskin was not exposed directly to the Celestial Atlas, star atlases in general stood behind more accessible introductory‐level texts, and Jamiesonʼs atlas in particular was plagiarized by British astronomical primers of the 1820s.
Scientific and Practical Astronomical Dialogues
Ruskinʼs foundational reading about astronomy was in the form of educational dialogues, of which the earliest was likelu John Aikin and Letitia Barbauld's Evenings at Home (see Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth: Physical Descriptions of Some Books Used by Ruskin in Boyhood and Youth--Beinecke no. 4; and Hanson, “Materiality in John Ruskinʼs Early Letters and Dialogues”, 29-30). The conversations on astronomy are widely interspersed among other topics, thus playing out difficult and abstract concepts gradually and building on one another. On the fourteenth evening, a dialogue between Papa and Lucy, "Why an Apple Falls", leads from reasoning about the force of gravitation on small objects to the forces commanding the earth as a "vast ball . . . continually spinning around", which "is the cause why the sun and stars seem to rise and set". The dialogue ends by asking "why the earth does not fall into the sun". (Apropos, this dialogue is preceded by a poem, "Phaeton Junior; or, The Gig Demolished", a homely version of the myth.) This problem is revived on the nineteenth evening in "Why the Earth Moves Round the Sun", summoning everyday examples to explain centrifugal and centripetal forces, which "[b]y the wonderful skill of the Creator . . . were made exactly to counterbalance each other; so that just as much as the earth . . . tends to fly forwards, just so much the sun draws it to the centre". Finally, on the thirtieth evening in "A Globe Lecture", Papa reminds Lucy where they left the topic of the earth's orbit and teaches Lucy the use of a globe in understanding the world's climates and their influence on vegetation, animals, and human cultures, leaving an explanation of the solar system for another day when he will "take you to the lecture of an ingenious philosopher who has contrived a machine that will give you a better notion" of the planetary movements--an orrery, which Ruskin would next have read about in Maria Edgeworth's final volumes of her Early Lessons series, Frank: A Sequel and Harry and Lucy Concuded (Aikin and Barbauld, Evenings at Home, 3:127-28, 129, 115-21; 4:117-18; 6:123).
here
and the most cherished, are directly revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. The Tutor points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a wagon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear end of the wagon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, Coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).
In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel, the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where Frank can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of a dark moor because he understood the guidance of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harry Sandfordʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.
In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:
Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)
Ruskinʼs poem “The Constellations” is his answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem along with Harryʼs drawing effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs somewhat random and poeticized listing the star clusters carries out in its own way the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs his pupils, Charles and James, in the names and positions of the constellations.
In the opening of “The Constellations”, the tutelage of Dayʼs, Joyceʼs, and Edgeworthʼs practical and scientific astronomy lessons is perceptible in the tactic of starting from a prominent point of reference in the sky, although not, in Ruskinʼs case, with a constellation, but with a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, which is a wandering rather than a fixed star. “Dost thou see”, the poem asks, how Venus is associated with the constellation Orion as these bodies fall below the horizon in the west? From there, the poem turns to the next planet on the ecliptic, Mars, and then re‐orients to the circumpolar constellations overhead. The method does not adopt Tommy Sandfordʼs more practical and reliable recommendation of first finding Charlesʼs Wain and then tracing its pointer stars to the Pole Star; instead, Ruskinʼs sequence starts from “stars” traditionally regarded as the most beautiful—the Evening Star and Orionʼs Belt, “a glorious sight for all sky loving men”—and thence carries on to the circumpolar formations. From this more sublimely oriented beginning, the poem does proceed to follow Mr. Barlowʼs advice, that “by remembering these stars [of Charlesʼs Wain], you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). As Ruskinʼs poem clicks along, however, while repeating “next” and “next” the sequence becomes erratic. As suggested by the poemʼs title, which Ruskin appears to have extended belatedly in order to account for “some of the zodiac and some of the southern” constellations that had found their way into the poem along with the survey of the visible “northern” sky (see Title), the sequence reveals a logic at best only intermittently (see Real‐life Observations). Aware of the systematic procedure advised by his booksʼ astronomy lessons, he added the caveat, “These constellations though they are next in this poetry are not next in the sky”, to the second and final fair copy (MS III). Whatever led his fancy, the poem is livelier than Mrs. Sherwoodʼs bare and wooden lists set up alongside Bible verses for rote memorization.
In 1828, if they had acquired Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas, its exercises would surely have demanded too much of Ruskinʼs abilities. As remarked previously, the random order in which he names constellations in his poem suggests that he failed to master even the most basic astronomical concepts, as presented in Mrs. Sherwoodʼs elementary primer. Nonetheless, the atlas would have appealed not only in its visual depictions and prose summaries of myths; it would also have bolstered Ruskinʼs pride in British achievements in astronomical discovery and science. A consistent theme in Ruskinʼs poem is his observance of constellations with British associations, such as Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), Robur Caroli (Charlesʼs Oak), and Telescopium Herschelii (Herschellʼs Telescope).
Mrs. Sherwood advises: “A teacher, when hearing the class, should use globes, or plates, such as may be found in most elementary books of astronomy, to assist the children in understanding what they learn” (Introduction to Astronomy, vii). Plates and globes depicted the mythical figures for which the constellations were named; and plates were found in star atlases, which among other information related the stories associated with the stars and constellations, such as the myth of the Milky Way (Via Lactea) that Ruskin uses to frame his conclusion to the second fair copy (MS III): “the ancients thought” it “the road / Which all their best and bravest trod / Unto great Jupiters blest abode”.
Still, a confirmed source of Ruskinʼs exposure to the mythology of the constellations remains elusive, as does a measure of his knowledge of those stories. The contextual glosses identify the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem and summarize their stories, drawing on two sources published in the 1820s: Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas and an American work (partly dependent on Jamiesonʼs), Astronomical Recreations (1824) by Jacob Green (1790‐1841). How familiar this information would have been to Ruskin himself in this period is unknown.
